awd_titl_txt: Eager: Automated Synthesis for System Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthesis is the process of computing an implementation from a specification of the desired behavior, performance, and security and privacy properties.  This ideal form of system design has been a long-standing dream in computer science.  The goal of this project is to realize the dream of synthesis, in the same way that current tools for program analysis and model checking realize the dream of verifying program correctness. This is feasible today due to the enormous computing power of today's platforms and due to the recent significant technical advances in the underlying technologies for program analysis and verification. Synthesis, supported by powerful computational tools, and integrated into system design, can have a transformative effect by enabling the construction of more complex and more robust systems than are currently possible or cost effective.

The focus of this project is the development of algorithmic tools for assertion-based design synthesis.  We will develop automata- and game-theoretic approach to assertion-based intentional system design.  The intellectual merit of this project is the interplay between games, automata, and logic.  Based on deep theoretical foundations, prototype synthesis tools will be developed.  These are crucial for the development of reliable, secure, and scalable computing systems.

por.por_cntn:
Synthesis is the process of computing an implementation from a specification of the desired behavior and performance and assumptions on the environment. This ideal form of system design has been a  long-standing dream in computer science.  This project has made substantial progress in realizing the dream of synthesis, in the same way that current tools for program analysis and model checking realize the dream of verifying program correctness. Such progress is feasible today due to the enormous computing power of today's platforms and due to the recent significant technical advances in the underlying technologies for program analysis and verification.  Synthesis, supported by powerful computational tools, and integrated into system design, is expected to have a transformative effect by enabling the construction of more complex and more robust systems than are currently possible or cost effective. By incorporating synthesis--a computationally demanding problem--in the design loop, we are allowing the enormous computational power routinely available to all programmers these days, to assist in the task of system design itself. Overall, we expect to see a transformative change in the way robust systems are designed and developed, by enabling designers to specify systems at natural levels of abstractions and providing computational tools to derive correct implementations.

The focus of the project has been the development of algorithmic tools for  assertion-based design synthesis.  We developed automata- and   game-theoretic approach to assertion-based intentional system design.   While the main focus of games and automata has traditionally been on  finite objects (or very simple infinite ones), we extended this approach to the more complex situations that we face in most practical applications, and for which the method is not yet sufficiently developed or exploited. By  exploring the interplay between games, automata, and logic,  we made fundamental progress in this area, aimed at the development of automated design techniques, which are crucial for the development of reliable, robust, and scalable computing systems.
